instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2875: What is 820-2875? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5_REG: What is PP3V3_S5_REG? PP3V3_S5_REG is a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state. .
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.SYS_ONEWIRE: What is SYS_ONEWIRE? This is a bidirectional communication line between the system management controller(SMC) and the charger that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC. This must be working for the light to come on on the magsafe charger. .
definitions.ADAPTER_SENSE: What is ADAPTER_SENSE? This is a line between the onewire circuit and the magsafe charger where the magsafe charger can talk to the SMC(system management controller) on the SYS_ONEWIRE line..
definitions.820-2879: What is 820-2879? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.P5VS3_EN_L: What is P5VS3_EN_L? P5VS3_EN_L is a signal that enables the PP5V_S3 power rail when it is low.  _L means whatever before the _L in the signal name is asserted when it is low voltage, such as 0.0v to 0.5v..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_REG</SIGNAL> missing no green light
threads.message:
I got this board no green light, I figured out that <SIGNAL>SYS_ONEWIRE</SIGNAL> was missing, then realized someone already blasted smc with heatgun, I reballed smc, <SIGNAL>SYS_ONEWIRE</SIGNAL> returned. <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H_ONEWIRE</SIGNAL> present
<SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> 3.3
<SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL> 2.8v


Still no green light, now figured <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_REG</SIGNAL> missing, somewhere a long the way I replaced <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>.
ENTRIP2 and ENTRIP1 and <SIGNAL>5V3V3_REG_EN</SIGNAL> (0.5v) missing, do I have a case of bad smc? if so is it as simple as finding a same one or I need to anything else with it?

VIN 12v, VREG3 and VREG5 are present on <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_REG</SIGNAL> missing no green light
threads.message: is there reason why I dont get any answers?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_REG</SIGNAL> missing no green light
threads.message:
Maybe the wrong code you gave us...
Surely iPad2?
It is not <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_REG</SIGNAL> missing no green light
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> on most boards is controlled by SMC. If you still don't have green light we can't do anything with <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> yet. If the board was previously blasted with heatgun to SMC, then likely the SMC is damaged/dead, so needs replacing. Get green light first. Then go for everything else!

[QUOTE="Dmitry, post: 14784"]is there reason why I dont get any answers?[/QUOTE]

Yes, you posted this 3 hours ago. Instant replies are available for additional $1k/mo/member.

You gave number for an iPad 2, but are giving rails/signals for a Macbook. What board are we working with here?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_REG</SIGNAL> missing no green light
threads.message:
[QUOTE="larossmann, post: 14797"]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> on most boards is controlled by SMC. If you still don't have green light we can't do anything with <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> yet. If the board was previously blasted with heatgun to SMC, then likely the SMC is damaged/dead, so needs replacing. Get green light first. Then go for everything else!



Yes, you posted this 3 hours ago. Instant replies are available for additional $1k/mo/member.

You gave number for an iPad 2, but are giving rails/signals for a Macbook. What board are we working with here?[/QUOTE]

<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> is the right number, so after smc replacement do I have to flash anything? I dont have much experience with macbooks, but with regular laptops I need to flash it some time when replacing multi-controller. is that the case with  macbooks?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_REG</SIGNAL> missing no green light
threads.message:
Does something change on the symptom?
Give us some voltages on the board.
Did you get green light?
Help us to help you...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_REG</SIGNAL> missing no green light
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 14844"]Does something change on the symptom?
Give us some voltages on the board.
Did you get green light?
Help us to help you...[/QUOTE]

I gave the voltages in my first post. nothing was changed , Louis kind of confirming that my smc probably bad and I asked if it is as simple as installing new one, or I have to flash/reset anything.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_REG</SIGNAL> missing no green light
threads.message: No flash/reset. If <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is high, then you can go ahead and replace SMC. Must be taken from another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> of course.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_REG</SIGNAL> missing no green light
threads.message:
Posted voltages are insufficient.
BTW "VIN 12v" is useless.
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 12.3V, or 12.55V; the exact value will tell us a lot!
Do you have voltage at L7750?
Also measure <CHIP>U7840</CHIP> and <CHIP>U5010</CHIP>.
<SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SYS_ONEWIRE</SIGNAL> should have the same value; only you can measure...
Check if central pin of magsafe has the same voltage too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_REG</SIGNAL> missing no green light
threads.message:
[QUOTE="larossmann, post: 14858"]No flash/reset. If <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is high, then you can go ahead and replace SMC. Must be taken from another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> of course. [/QUOTE]

<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - is high (3.4v), 

I didnt find <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> for reasonable price on ebay, But i do have <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that I got from ebay for $30, it has the same smc code, so I tried that on my board since it looks like last chance for repair.

After replacement of SMC few things has changed.
green light on
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_REG</SIGNAL> is present now
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - is high (3.4v) still high

<CHIP>U7200</CHIP>
=<SIGNAL>P5VS3_EN_L</SIGNAL>- low
ENTRIP2 - 0.7v
<SIGNAL>3V3S5_VBST</SIGNAL> - is 8v wtf ?

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3_REG</SIGNAL> missing , why dont <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> generate it?

Vin is present, <SIGNAL>P5VS3_EN_L</SIGNAL> is low, what else? or it is

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_REG</SIGNAL> missing no green light
threads.message:
Pretty sure that SMC will not work there.
You swapped one from PCH platform to MCP (nVidia).
It must be from same <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>.
BTW, any <SIGNAL>X_EN_L</SIGNAL> signal should be low for working...
And that BST voltage is OK; learn how a buck converter works.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_REG</SIGNAL> missing no green light
threads.message: Different SMC firmware need to take from identical board. At least you know the original SMC is bad. Also these board do not auto power on, need to short the power pads.
